indicators.justification:
The data available is outside of the study period. The data from the government is not well put together and is difficult to navigate. GHG Platform India makes the GHG emissions data available at a granular level making it usable. 
The data used for arriving at the GHG dataset is from published, secondary sources, or wholly or in part from the government sources. However the treatment of the data and the methodology for calculating emissions at a granular level is from GHG Platform India. GHG Platform India has also been recognized by the government in their Second Biennial Update Report
to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change(Section 6.6).

Sources:
GHG Platform India Secretariat. GHG Platform India.
http://www.ghgplatform-india.org/

The information on public consultation can be barely called a dataset. First, a proper dataset which houses all the public consultation information and administrative data needs to be collated and made available to the public. Second, there has to be more transparency inviting and accepting public comments - reasoned responses, some mechanism of feedback to stakeholders.

indicators.justification:
There are some events and challenges organised by the Open Government Data (OGD) Platform India to support and encourage data reuse. There is no such policy/guidelines/resources present that hint at such strategy. In some cases, the events/challenges are scheduled after a gap of 1-2 years. There are a few workshops regarding open data facilitated by the govt.; they are mostly on data visualization, not specifically on data reuse. There is substantial criticism of the open license of government data use along the lines of infringing of provisions granted to citizens under the Right to Information Act. indicators.justification:
The Information Technology Act, 2000 (the "IT Act") read with the Information Technology (Reasonable Security Practices and Procedures and Sensitive Personal Data or Information) Rules, 2011 (the "SPDI Rules", together with the IT Act "Data Protection Laws") contain specific provisions governing protection of personal data in India. 

In 2017, the Supreme Court of India upheld that privacy is a fundamental right, which is entrenched in Article 21 [Right to Life & Liberty] of the Constitution. This led to the formulation of a comprehensive Personal Data Protection Bill 2019 (the PDP Bill). The enactment of the PDP Bill will overhaul the personal data protection and regulatory regime in India. The PDP Bill is currently pending consideration of the Indian Parliament.

indicators.justification:
Collection and publication of data on the performance of right to information (RTI) is enshrined in Section 25 (Monitoring and Reporting), of The Right to Information Act, 2005. Every Public Authority is required to submit four quarterly returns for assessment of their performance during a year. The Commission is required to prepare an Annual Report after the end of each year on the implementation of the provisions of the RTI Act during that year. Even though there is no provision or collection of how long it took respective ministeries to service the requests there is a cap of 30 days within which the RTI request must be processed.

Source:
Ministry of Personnel, Public Grievances and Pensions. (2005, June 15). The Right to Information Act

https://rti.gov.in/rti-act.pdf
